14        Appendix 5 
 
PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The Government of Cambodia has identified the proposed project components to be 
covered under the ensuing loan project. It is required to conduct a project preparatory technical 
assistance (TA) and develop a project suitable for ADB funding in terms of technical, financial, 
economic, institutional, sector policy, legal, and safeguard contexts, in conjunction with the 
country partnership strategy, operational experience, and lessons from evaluations of previous 
projects. In the case of Battambang, project components covered under a pre-feasibility study of 
the Cities Development Initiative for Asia (CDIA) may be considered for funding under this 
project. This project will promote economic ties with the rural hinterland of the Tonle Sap Basin 
and create synergies between other ADB interventions in agriculture, natural resources, roads 
and rural water supply.1 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
 
2.  The ensuing investment project will comprise the following subsectors: (i) flood control and 
riverbank protection; (ii) solid waste management; (iii) sanitation and waste water treatment; and 
(iv) institutional capacity strengthening. Selection of prioritized subsectors (on average one to two 
subsectors per city or town) and their details will be determined during the TA. The institutional 
capacity strengthening component will help (i) increase efficiency and management capacity of 
the  relevant  local  government  agencies;  and  (ii)  raise  public  awareness  on  environmental 
protection. 
 
3.  The TA will be implemented in two phases. The first phase will develop strategic urban 
development plans that will guide the future urban growth. The second phase will determine the 
feasibility of the proposed investments for priority infrastructure construction and improvement 
covering (i) preliminary engineering designs; (ii) cost estimates and financing plan; (iii) financial 
and economic viability and sustainability; (iv) environmental and social soundness, and detailed 
implementation arrangements; and (v) prepare an institutional capacity strengthening program. 
The  TA  will  also  prepare  the  project  administration  manual  (PAM)  that  includes  all  the 
information and schedules describing project implementation. The major outputs and activities 
of the TA are summarized in Table A5.1.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement

financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB  (to  be  determined).  The  Government  will  finance  the 
remaining $200,000 equivalent in-kind. The Government was advised that approval of the TA 
does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. The detailed cost estimate is presented in 
Table A5.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
 
5.  All consultants will be engaged through firm(s). The TA will require 7 positions and 13 
person-months (pm) of international consulting services and 10 positions and 45 pm of national 
consulting services. ADB will select and engage consultants according to ADB’s Guidelines on 
Use of Consultants (April 2010, as amended from time to time). An international consulting firm 
shall be hired by following quality and cost-based selection (QCBS) method, using the “QCBS 
(80:20)”.  A simplified technical proposal will be required.

6.  The outline terms of reference for the TA consultants are described in paras. 7-19.

Appendix 5  17    
 
 
7.  The team leader will (i) assist in the overall organization of the TA; (ii) guide, supervise, 
and coordinate the work of all team members; and (iii) take overall responsibility for preparing 
reports and consolidating reports prepared by all team members. The deputy team leader will 
assist the team leader to accomplish tasks. 
 
8.  The international and national urban development specialists will (i) review existing 
urban  development  policies,  plans,  reports,  standards,  and  studies;  (ii)  assess  future 
development  needs;  (iii)  assess  the  existing  institutional  framework  for  urban  planning, 
development,  and  management;  (iv)  prepare  recommendations  for  improvements;  and  (v) 
develop a strategic city development plan that will guide the future urban growth. 
 
9.  The international and national urban development specialists, international municipal 
engineer/civil engineer-procurement specialist, national civil engineer, and international and 
national solid waste management specialists will (i) coordinate the preparation of a topographic 
map for the project area on a scale of 1/5,000; (ii) consult key stakeholders to identify major 
issues and bottlenecks to urban service delivery; (iii) confirm the priority areas and finalize the 
infrastructure  investment  subprojects;  (iv)  collect  and  analyze  information  on  urban 
infrastructure and civil works; (v) prepare preliminary engineering design and cost estimates; (vi) 
prepare an operation and maintenance plan; and (vii) prepare the project administration manual 
(PAM), assess procurement capacity, and prepare procurement plan and bid documents. 
 
10.  The  international  economist/municipal  finance  specialist/private  sector  participation 
specialist  and  national  finance  specialist/accountant  will  (i)  conduct  financial  management 
assessment  and  recommend  measures  to  strengthen  financial  management  capacities;  (ii) 
prepare a project financing plan, and design the funds flow and disbursement mechanism; (iii) 
propose auditor arrangements; (iv) prepare a financial analysis for the solid waste management 
component  if  it  relates  to  a  single  solid  waste  management  entity  which  operates  as  a 
commercial entity; and (v) forecast the incremental recurrent costs to ascertain the long-term 
impact of the Project. 
 
11.  The  international  economist/municipal  finance  specialist/private  sector  participation 
specialist and national economist will (i) conduct socioeconomic surveys and prepare baseline 
data; (ii) review the government initiatives in engaging private sector; (iii) assess opportunities 
and constraints for private sector participation in urban development; (iv) prepare a ‘strength, 
weakness, opportunities, and threats’ analysis; (v) refine the project rationale; (vi) prepare 
economic analyses for individual project components as well as the project as a whole following 
ADB's  guidelines;  and  (vii)  identify  the  areas  for  improving  the  regulatory  and  institutional 
framework. 
 
12.  The national procurement specialist, with support from the team leader, will (i) conduct 
the procurement capacity assessment; (ii) prepare a procurement plan; and (iii) identify specific 
advance actions with funding sources, time frame, and responsibilities. 
 
13.  The  international  and  national  environment  specialists  will  (i)  collect  data  on 
environmental conditions, (ii) assess the environmental impacts of the infrastructure works; and 
(iii) prepare an initial environmental examination according to ADB Safeguard Policy Update, 
2009. 
 
14.  The international social development/resettlement specialist and national resettlement 
specialist will (i) help conduct socioeconomic surveys; (ii) review the Government policies and

18  Appendix 5 
strategies  for  poverty  reduction;  (iii)  conduct  a  public  perception  survey  to  identify  public 
problems  and  development  priorities;  (iv)  conduct  a  poverty  and  social  analysis  (including 
willingness and ability to pay for services); (v) prepare a poverty and social strategy (including 
participation of women in operation and maintenance of facilities); (vi) develop gender targets in 
the  design  and  monitoring  framework;  (vii)  prepare  a  participatory  strategy  (including 
employment opportunities through labor-intensive implementation of civil works); (viii) prepare 
resettlement  plans  (RPs)  according  to  ADB  Safeguard  Policy  Update,  2009;  (ix)  help  the 
government initiate a participatory process for RP preparation; (x) assess the capacity of the 
responsible institutions to plan, update, and implement RPs, and propose training programs; 
and  (xi)  prepare  an  indigenous  peoples  plan  if  limited  impact  on  indigenous  peoples  is 
expected. 
 
15.  The international gender specialist will (i) review the government policies and strategies 
for gender development; (ii) collect sex-disaggregated data for possible gender targets used in 
the project; and (iii) prepare a gender action plan. 
 
16.  The  international  institutional  development  specialist  and  the  national  capacity 
building/institutional  specialist  will  (i)  identify  policy,  institutional,  and  human  resource 
bottlenecks for urban planning and management; (ii) assess the managerial, technical, and 
administrative capacities; (iii) prepare realistic project implementation arrangements; (iv) review 
existing  training  programs;  (v)  prepare  an  institutional  analysis;  and  (vi)  develop  capacity 
development programs. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  The  Ministry  of  Public  Works  and  Transport  (MPWT)  will  be  the  executing  agency 
responsible for preparation and implementation of the project. A national project coordinator will 
be appointed by the MPWT to undertake overall project coordination. During the TA, capacities 
of concerned local government agencies will be assessed. A project management unit (PMU) 
will be established under the MPWT and will be properly staffed with full time staff and an 
English-speaking coordinator. Representatives from the participating cities and towns and the 
Offices of Public Works and Transport of concerned provinces will participate in the PMU. The 
PMU will be responsible for coordinating detailed preparation and implementation of project 
activities. The Thematic Working Group on infrastructure and regional integration will provide 
policy guidance. The MPWT will provide the TA consultants with an office accommodation, 
qualified counterpart staff, office administrative support services and logistics, and necessary 
data and reports. The provincial MPWT branches in the participating cities or towns will be the 
implementing agencies and these will be involved during the TA. 
 
18.  Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with the ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, amended from time to time). The consultants 
may procure equipment through shopping in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2010, amended from time to time). Upon completion of the TA, equipment procured under the 
TA will be transferred to the MPWT. 
 
19.  The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A5.4.
